document_title: Partial weight suspension: a novel murine model for investigating adaptation to reduced musculoskeletal loading
summary_full: This study developed and validated a novel partial weight suspension (PWS) system in mice to simulate reduced gravity environments and investigate musculoskeletal adaptations. The system allows for adjustable weight bearing from 10% to 80% of normal body weight on all four limbs while enabling quadrupedal locomotion. Ten-week-old female mice were subjected to Mars-analog suspension (38% weight bearing) for 21 days and compared to age-matched controls. The PWS model successfully induced significant reductions in muscle mass (-23%), trabecular bone volume (-24%), cortical thickness (-11%), and femoral biomechanical properties (-27%) in the Mars-analog group compared to controls. Bone formation rates were decreased, while resorption remained largely unchanged. The model demonstrated low animal stress after an initial adaptation period, with no significant differences in weight gain between groups after the first week. The study concludes that this PWS model is a valuable tool for exploring musculoskeletal responses to reduced loading, with implications for spaceflight and clinical conditions.
key_findings: Developed a novel partial weight suspension (PWS) system for mice, allowing tunable reduced loading (10-80%) on all four limbs.
Mars-analog suspension (38% weight bearing) for 21 days significantly reduced gastrocnemius muscle mass by 23%.
PWS led to significant reductions in trabecular bone volume (-24%) and cortical thickness (-11%) in the femur.
Biomechanical properties of the femur were significantly reduced by 27% in the PWS group.
Bone formation indexes decreased in suspended mice, while resorption parameters were largely unchanged.
The PWS model showed low animal stress after an initial adaptation period, with normal weight gain in subsequent weeks.
future_research_fields: Investigating the threshold of loading beyond which skeletal degradation slows.
Exploring countermeasures against bone loss in spaceflight, bed rest, and other catabolic states.
Delineating the effects of partial weight bearing versus full unloading on musculoskeletal adaptations.
Studying the role of fluid shift in musculoskeletal changes during reduced gravity.
Examining neuromuscular adaptations and disuse-induced muscle loss following chronic partial weight bearing.
Monitoring activity levels and body composition changes in future studies.

conclusions: The developed partial weight suspension (PWS) system is a robust and tunable model for simulating reduced musculoskeletal loading in mice. Three weeks of Mars-analog loading resulted in significant muscle and bone loss, consistent with disuse atrophy, and demonstrated reduced bone formation. This model provides a valuable platform for investigating countermeasures and understanding adaptations to reduced gravity environments relevant to spaceflight and clinical conditions.
impact_statement: This study presents a novel and adaptable murine model for simulating reduced gravity, offering crucial insights into musculoskeletal deconditioning relevant to both space exploration and terrestrial clinical conditions.
